title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by recognizing the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes and a distinct Indian community. The State of North Carolina has recognized the Lumbee Indians as an Indian tribe since 1885. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina have been recognized as a distinct Indian community since contact with white settlers. The State of North Carolina acknowledged them as an Indian tribe in 1885, and in 1956, the US Congress also recognized them as a tribe but withheld federal benefits. Now, it is proposed that the Lumbee Indians should receive full federal recognition. The Lumbee Indians, a federally recognized tribe, should now be entitled to full Federal recognition of their status as an Indian tribe, with all benefits, privileges, and immunities accorded to them. The Lumbee Indians, a federally recognized tribe, should now be entitled to full Federal recognition of their status as an Indian tribe. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, ensuring that all laws and regulations applicable to Indians and Indian tribes apply to them and their members. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for federal recognition and all services and benefits provided to Indians. Members residing in specific counties may petition for tribal acknowledgement under federal regulations. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for federal services and benefits as members of a federally recognized tribe. Members residing in certain counties are considered to be residing on or near an Indian reservation. Upon verification of a tribal roll, a determination of needs and budget will be developed in consultation with the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, eligible for federal services, will have a determination of needs and budget developed in consultation with the tribe for services members are eligible for. The tribal roll in effect at the time of enactment will be used for the delivery of Federal services. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina will have a budget request submitted to Congress based on the verified tribal roll. The Secretary of the Interior will verify compliance with membership criteria within one year of the enactment. The tribe may convey fee lands to the United States. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina's constitution, adopted in 2000, requires verification of tribal membership within one year. Fee lands can be conveyed to the United States for trust if located in Robeson County. North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on tribal lands. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers of land on behalf of the United States. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers of land on behalf of the United States from the State of North Carolina, involving the Lumbee Tribe. The transfer of jurisdiction may take effect after 2 years of the agreement, and it does not affect the application of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978.
